snippet: After laboratory studies and driving tests confirming the risks of next-day drowsiness, the Food and Drug Administration said that women should be taking half as much.
abstract: Food and Drug Administration says women should be taking half as much of prescription sleep aids like Ambien, after laboratory studies and driving tests confirmed risks of next-day drowsiness; about 60 million prescriptions were dispensed in 2011, up about 20 percent since 2006.

byline.contributor: Andrew Pollack contributed reporting from San Francisco.

lead_paragraph: After laboratory studies and driving tests confirming the risks of next-day drowsiness, the Food and Drug Administration said that women should be taking half as much.

headline.seo: F.D.A. Requires Cuts to Dosages of Ambien and Other Sleep Drugs
headline.main: Drug Agency Recommends Lower Doses of Sleep Aids for Women
headline.print_headline: Drug Agency Recommends Lower Doses of Sleep Aids for Women
